channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Afghanistan Itself Is Now Taking In the Most Afghan Migrants
item.media:description: A truck carried the belongings of a repatriated Afghan refugee family across the border with Pakistan into Afghanistan in September.
item.description: By the end of the year, officials expect some 1.5 million migrants to return to Afghanistan — many of them forcibly, and including some registered as refugees.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: How Is Your Family Coping With Delhi’s Air Pollution?
item.media:description: Burning paddies, like this one Thursday on a farm in the Indian state of Punjab, contributes to the poor air quality in New Delhi, the capital.
item.description: The Times would like to hear from parents whose children are staying home from school to avoid exposure to dangerous levels of air pollution.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Delhi Closes Over 1,800 Schools in Response to Dangerous Smog
item.media:description: Boys played soccer in a park on a smoggy morning in New Delhi on Wednesday.
item.description: The closings, part of an effort to shield children in India’s capital from air pollution, affect more than a million students.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: A New Vladimir Overlooking Moscow
item.media:description: The monument to Vladimir, the patron saint of the Russian Orthodox Church, about 100 yards from the Kremlin walls in Moscow. Critics view it as a thinly disguised homage to President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.description: The 60-foot statue of St. Vladimir, patron saint of the Russian Orthodox Church, is part of wave monument building that seems meant to glorify more than historical figures.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Will Require a Vote in Parliament, U.K. Court Rules
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May had planned to begin the legal steps for leaving the European Union by the end of March, and to prepare for the negotiations over Britain’s exit mostly behind closed doors.
item.description: The High Court decision on negotiations over Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union seemed likely to slow — but not halt — the process.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Turkey’s Post-Coup Crackdown Targets Kurdish Politicians
item.media:description: Turkish police officers detained Sebahat Tuncel, who formerly represented the pro-Kurdish Peoples’ Democracy Party in Parliament, on Friday during a demonstration outside Diyarbakir’s courthouse.
item.description: Critics have accused President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of using the failed coup as a pretext to neutralize all opposition, notably the main pro-Kurdish party.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and SAFAK TIMUR

item.title: Protest at Athens Mosque Site Ends With 15 Arrests
item.media:description: Members of a right-wing group occupying the site for a mosque in Athens in October. The group was removed by the Greek police on Friday.
item.description: Members of nationalist groups had been occupying a site that Greece had set aside for its first state-sponsored mosque — a plan that predated an influx of migrants.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Ruling Could Cause Britain to Drag Its Feet, Muddying E.U. Plans
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain sought to reassure European leaders that her timetable for withdrawal from the bloc would not be derailed, despite a High Court ruling on Thursday that requires her to consult Parliament first.
item.description: Prime Minister Theresa May tried to soothe the nerves of Britain’s European partners on Friday, after her strategy to leave the European Union was imperiled.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: News Analysis: Iraqis Fear ‘Bloodshed Will Continue’ After Mosul if Sectarian Tensions Aren’t Addressed
item.media:description: Displaced people on Tuesday at a checkpoint near Qaiyara, south of Mosul, Iraq.
item.description: Analysts warn that even a complete military victory over the Islamic State in Mosul will not change the reality that there is still no political agreement in place.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: 3 U.S. Military Trainers Killed at Jordan Air Base
item.description: An exchange of gunfire occurred as the service members vehicles approached the gate of the base in Al Jafr, in southern Jordan, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Iran Sentences Rioters Who Stormed Saudi Diplomatic Posts
item.description: Iranian suspects who stormed Saudi diplomatic missions in early this year were sentenced to prison.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Cashless Economy in Zimbabwe? With Little Cash, There’s Little Choice
item.media:description: Customers lined up outside an FBC Bank branch in Harare, Zimbabwe, on Tuesday.
item.description: Debit card machines are proliferating in churches, supermarkets and nightclubs as anxious Zimbabweans hoard American dollars or take them out of the country.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MOYO and NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Matter: Ebola Evolved Into Deadlier Enemy During the African Epidemic
item.media:description: A burial team in Bong County, Liberia, buried a suspected Ebola victim in October 2014. The Ebola epidemic that hit West Africa that year claimed 11,310 lives.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: A mutated version of the virus was more effective at entering human cells, scientists report. The finding may help explain the vast scope of the last outbreak.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: Abroad in America: Your Questions About the U.S. Election, Answered
item.media:description: A large crowd gathered at the Harlem Tavern in New York City to watch the third debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.description: We invited readers to tell us what they want to know about the presidential campaign. Here are some responses ahead of the election.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: What in the World: Billboard, Souvenir, Metaphor: The Many Uses of a German Beer Coaster
item.media:description: Waiters mark coasters with a line for each beer a customer is served. At the end of the night, the patron shows his often soggy tab to a cashier, who flips it over and calculates the final bill on the back.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Anywhere that kegs are tapped in Germany, you’ll find the pressed-paper discs known as bierdeckel — and people who creatively repurpose them.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: If China Meant to Chill Hong Kong Speech, Booksellers’ Case Did the Job
item.media:description: Lam Wing-kee, left, one of five Hong Kong booksellers who went missing last year, outside the bookstore at the center of the case during a protest last June.
item.description: A report by PEN America outlines the circumstances behind the disappearances of five booksellers last year and the fear that their case has sown in the industry.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: China Plans to Intervene in Hong Kong Dispute
item.media:description: The recently elected lawmakers Yau Wai-ching, center-left, and Sixtus Leung, center-right, outside the Legislative Council building in Hong Kong on Wednesday.
item.description: The debate is whether two politicians should be allowed to take seats in the local legislature after altering the oath of office.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: A Slow Ride Toward the Future of Public Transportation
item.media:description: A self-driving bus in Helsinki, Finland, which has been at the forefront of efforts to use technology to rethink public transportation.
item.media:credit: Ugri Touko Tapani Hujanen for The New York Times
item.description: A self-driving bus being tested in Finland holds promise for reducing cities’ dependence on cars.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: From Hong Kong Pencil Pusher to Political Firebrand
item.media:description: Ms. Yau at her swearing-in ceremony on Oct. 12. She used an expletive and laid out a banner that read “Hong Kong Is Not China.”
item.description: At 25, and after thumbing her nose at Beijing, Yau Wai-ching has emerged as the best-known and most provocative public figure in the former British colony.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: Islamists March in Jakarta, Demanding Christian Governor Be Jailed
item.media:description: Tens of thousands marched on Friday in Jakarta, Indonesia, against Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, an ethnic Chinese Christian running for re-election as the city’s governor.
item.description: Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, the first Christian leader of the Indonesian capital in decades, has been accused of blasphemy as he runs for re-election.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Sting to Perform at Reopening of Bataclan a Year After Paris Attacks
item.media:description: Sting performing in Melbourne, Australia, last month. The singer said his Nov. 12 show at the Bataclan concert hall in Paris would “respect the memory as well as the life-affirming spirit” of those who died there.
item.description: The British musician said he would appear at the inaugural show on Nov. 12, almost 12 months to the day after a terrorist assault at the venue killed 90 people.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA

item.title: South Korean Leader Says She Will Submit to Scandal Inquiry
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea addressed the nation in Seoul on Friday.
item.description: President Park Geun-hye says she’s willing to submit to questioning by prosecutors looking into troubles that have engulfed her administration.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Turkey Detains Leaders of Kurdish Opposition Party
item.media:description: Selahattin Demirtas, second from right, co-leader of the Peoples’ Democratic Party, attended a pro-Kurdish demonstration in Diyarbakir, Turkey, last month.
item.description: The leaders, Selahattin Demirtas and Figen Yuksekdag of the Peoples’ Democratic Party, were detained as part of a counterterrorism investigation, state news media reported.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Egypt Floats Currency, Appeasing I.M.F. at Risk of Enraging Poor
item.media:description: A store in Cairo selling subsidized goods last month. Allowing the Egyptian pound to devalue, even temporarily, will most likely raise the prices of subsidized staples like bread, sugar, rice and cooking oil.
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.description: The move, which effectively devalues the Egyptian pound, is part of an effort to secure a desperately needed rescue loan from the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF and DIAA HADID

item.title: Killing of Saudi Student Shakes Wisconsin College Town
item.media:description: A memorial for Hussain Saeed Alnahdi outside Toppers Pizza on Main Street in Menomonie, Wis., on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Marisa Wojcik/The Eau Claire Leader-Telegram, via Associated Press
item.description: The police in Menomonie, Wis., have no motive in the death of Hussain Saeed Alnahdi, 24, but a $20,000 reward has been announced.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte’s Pledge to Stop Cursing Lands in the Gutter
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines in Pangasinan province on Wednesday.
item.description: The president of the Philippines, known for his salty language, broke his “promise to God” to stop swearing.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: More Than 200 Migrants Drown Off Libya Trying to Reach Europe
item.media:description: Migrants trying to make it across the Mediterranean on a rubber dinghy were rescued on Thursday by an aid group based in Malta and the Italian Red Cross.
item.description: The Mediterranean crossing has been increasingly deadly this year, even as fewer asylum seekers try to make it to Europe.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: The Interpreter: Rodrigo Duterte Plays U.S. and China Off Each Other, in Echo of Cold War
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines, right, and President Xi Jinping of China in Beijing in October. Mr. Duterte has exploited the rivalry between the United States and China, improving his position with both.
item.description: The Philippine president’s strategy of balancing between the powers by threatening to change loyalties was used successfully by leaders throughout the era.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: Article 50: Dusting Off the Road Map for ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Thousands demonstrated in London in July against a British exit from the European Union.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Britain voted in June to leave the European Union, but the process can begin only when the government invokes a previously unused treaty provision.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Paris Is the New Calais, With Scores of Migrants Arriving Daily
item.media:description: A migrant carrying his belongings at a camp on the Boulevard de la Villette in northern Paris on Monday.
item.description: Recent arrivals from Africa and Afghanistan have been living in pup tents in the city’s northern neighborhoods, creating a new crisis for the French.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: L’Aquila Journal: In Italy, a Town Still ‘Broken’ by a Quake. The One 7 Years Ago.
item.media:description: Restoration work at the Church of San Biagio in L’Aquila, which was struck by an earthquake in 2009. L’Aquila is a tale of two cities: part ghost town, part construction site.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.description: L’Aquila, devastated by a 2009 earthquake, is Italy’s largest construction site. Yet much of it still feels like a ghost town, a sobering sign for cities struck by more recent quakes.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: E.U. Official, Under Pressure for Having Disparaged the Chinese, Apologizes
item.media:description: Günther Oettinger, the European Union’s digital economy commissioner, in Berlin last year. He expressed remorse on Thursday for his recent comments about the Chinese.
item.description: Günther H. Oettinger, a European commissioner from Germany, expressed remorse for having described Chinese people as “slit-eyes” and “sly dogs.”
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Thailand Court Clears U.K. Labor Activist of Defaming Fruit Company
item.media:description: The British human rights activist Andy Hall arriving at the Supreme Court in Bangkok on Thursday.
item.description: The activist, Andy Hall, said he would appeal an earlier, separate conviction and sue the company he accused of abusing migrant workers.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Sinosphere: An 80-Year-Old Model Reshapes China’s Views on Aging
item.media:description: Wang Deshun, who turned 80 this fall, at the China Fashion Week in Beijing last year.
item.description: Wang Deshun, known as China’s hottest grandpa, is being venerated in the country as an example of how to grow old without fading away.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: 2 U.S. Soldiers and 30 Afghans Killed in Kunduz Battle
item.media:description: Relatives with the body of a man who was killed during clashes between Afghan security forces and the Taliban in Kunduz, Afghanistan, on Thursday.
item.description: Officials said the Afghan dead were civilians killed by airstrikes near the provincial capital, but differed on whether strikes were Afghan or American.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Crypt Believed to Be Jesus’ Tomb Opened for First Time in Centuries
item.media:description: Workers removing a marble top last week from the tomb said to be of Jesus Christ, in the Church of Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem.
item.media:credit: Dusan Vranic/National Geographic, via Associated Press
item.description: The tomb was opened as part of a renovation of the shrine that was built around it long after Jesus’ death in what today is known as the Church of the Holy Sepulcher.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Bolshoi Gives Building Pass to Dancer Involved in Acid Attack on its Director
item.media:description: The dancer Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, who was released from prison in May, said he received the building pass this fall from the Bolshoi’s new artistic director, the replacement for the man whom the dancer had targeted.
item.media:credit: Max Avdeev for The New York Times
item.description: Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, who was released from prison in May, said he received the pass this fall from the Bolshoi’s new artistic director.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Nicaragua, a Blatantly Rigged Election
item.media:description: President Daniel Ortega with his wife, Rosario Murillo, in July.
item.description: This weekend, under Daniel Ortega, sham democracy has come full circle, back to the vote-without-choice farce once practiced by the Somoza dynasty.
item.dc:creator: CARLOS F. CHAMORRO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Dalai Lama: Behind Our Anxiety, the Fear of Being Unneeded
item.description: There has never been a better time to be alive, and yet in the richest countries, there is a growing sense of unease and helplessness because people no longer feel useful.
item.dc:creator: THE DALAI LAMA and ARTHUR C. BROOKS

item.title: Contributing Opinion Writer: Is Donald Trump an American Hugo Chávez?
item.media:description: Mr. Trump, left, pits hard-working Middle America against the Washington establishment. Mr. Chávez, right, pitted the noble Venezuelan poor against what he called “the oligarchs” and the imperial United States.
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times, left, Jose Caruci , Agence France-Presse, right.
item.description: The Republican candidate and the deceased Venezuelan president are both populists by posture, if not ideology.
item.dc:creator: IOAN GRILLO

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
